loans.name: Zulfa

texts.en:
Zulfa is 21 years old. She is a young woman who is not married and lives with her parents in Morogoro Rural District.

Zulfa is a Camfed learner guide. She has a business of buying and selling women's clothes known as Khanga and Vitenge. The income supports her and her siblings. She uses some of her profit for helping the most vulnerable children.

Zulfa is requesting a Kiva loan in order to expand her business of women's clothes by buying in bulk. Zulfa has a dream of having a big shop of clothes and save more money for the future.

loans.use: to expand her women's clothes business.

loans.name: Mwalimdogo

texts.en:
Mwalimdogo is 23 years old and is a single mother of one child. She lives in Morogoro District in Tanzania. She is a Camfed Learner Guide who teaches students in secondary school life skills to boost their aptitude for learning. Apart from this, Mwalimdogo has a cosmetics shop. She chose this line of business to meet the demands of young girls and women in the community.

Mwalimdogo is requesting a loan from Kiva to increase the variety of products in her shop. She plans to use the profits from her business to send her child to school and to help support her family.

loans.use: to buy products for her cosmetics shop.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 29 years old. She is a mother of two children and lives with her parents in Morogoro District.

Flora is a committed Camfed Learner Guide. She teaches students life skills for studying and self-awareness for at least two and half hours per week.

Flora has a business selling charcoal. She is requesting a Kiva loan to build a simple room (store) for selling charcoal and to expand her business. Her vision is to save money for the purpose of sending her children to English middle school.

loans.use: to build a store for selling charcoal.

loans.name: Edith Drapeau

texts.fr: Edith a 62 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de six enfants. Elle tient une petite épicerie à domicile. Elle y vend des produits alimentaires. Elle cherche un microcrédit pour acheter des cartons d’œufs et des sacs de sucre jaune.
texts.en:
Edith is 62 years old. She is married and the mother of six children.

She runs a small grocery store from her home. She sells food products there.

She is seeking this micro-loan to buy cartons of eggs and bags of yellow sugar.

loans.use: to buy cartons of eggs and bags of yellow sugar

loans.name: Vivien

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Vivien works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines and also earns income from buying and selling livestock. Vivien is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her restaurant business.

Vivien has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Siamini

texts.en:
Siamini is 24 years old and is not married. She lives with her parents in Kilolo district. She volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide, teaching life skills to help students improve their performance.

She is requesting a Kiva loan to start a restaurant business in her village. The profit will help to repay the loan and fulfill her dreams of going back to school for further education.

loans.use: to start a restaurant business

loans.name: Hamza

texts.en:
Hamza is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, he has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. Before joining Babban Gona, Hamza would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs.

With the help of this loan, he can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, he will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. Hamza is thankful that he now has the opportunity to to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en:
Mwanamkasi is a married woman and has been blessed with eight children, one of whom attends school. Together with her husband, they live in their own house that has electricity but no piped water.

She has operated a fish selling business for over four years, selling from home to restaurant operators and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and perishability leading to losses.

With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase bundles of fish for resale. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish for resale

loans.name: Waida

texts.en:
Waida is 23 years old and she is not married. She lives with her parents in Kilolo district. She is the mother of one child. She volunteers as a Camfed Learner Guide, teaching life skills to help students improve their performance.

She is requesting a Kiva loan to start a restaurant business in her village. The profit will help to repay the loan and fulfill her dream of opening a bank account to save her profit for future use.

loans.use: to start a restaurant business in her village

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes, 22 years old, is married and the mother of one child. She is a Camfed learner guide who teaches students life skills at her nearby secondary school.

Agnes, who runs a mobile money transfer business, is requesting this Kiva loan to expand her enterprise by buying airtime from Airtel, Vodacom and Tigo and having more running capital to serve her customers. The profit obtained from the loan will help her to improve her business through increased M-Pesa and Tigo-pesa commissions.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying credit from Airtel, Vodacom and Tigo.

loans.name: Fuatau

texts.en:
Fuatau is a 31 years old married woman with two children. She bakes and sells donuts and ice cakes in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business.

Fuatau needs a loan to buy a bag of flour, a bag of sugar, cooking powder, an oven and a small freezer. She plans to use her profits to expand her business and to save for her children's education. Fuatau has been a member of SPBD since 2013.

loans.use: to buy a bag of flour, a bag of sugar, cooking powder, an oven and a small freezer.

loans.name: Enkhjargal

texts.en:
Enkhjargall is a 27 years old woman who lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She has been working as therapist at a local hospital since 2011. Her husband transports goods between districts for a living. They live in a ger (a portable felt dwelling) on a plot of land.

Enkhjargall is requesting a loan of 2000 USD to renovate her house which has been damaged severely during last summer due to heavy rain and storms. By doing so her family will live in comfortable and warm place where less coal is burned, releasing less pollutant into air.

loans.use: to renovate her house, which was damaged by rain and storms.

loans.name: Waliam

texts.en: Waliam is a 26-year-old Syrian citizen who has been employed in a small restaurant for four years and is working hard to improve his living. His work is located far from his house, and transportation is very hard in his region, which makes going to work — especially during the coming winter season — very hard to achieve. Thus, for this reason, Waliam is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy a motorcycle necessary for his transportation to work. He hopes that one day he can progress in his domain and open his own restaurant in the future.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle necessary for his transportation to daily work.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
In 2008, Alma learned about Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative and the financial assistance it gives start-ups. Alma tried her luck with doing a business focusing on her farming activities. She feels she owe her success to the Cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used as capital.

Alma borrowed another amount to pay for seedlings and compost. This will help give her farming income a big boost. Alma looks for better business opportunities and would love to be in the position to help others.

loans.use: to pay for seedlings and compost

location.town: Pagadian - Pagadian City, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a married man, with 6 children. He describes himself to be God fearing. He operates a carpentry where he makes and sells furniture. He has been involved in this business for 15 years. His primary customers are locals.

He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate equipment. He will use the Kes 100,000 loan to buy carpentry equipment. His business goal is to own a big furniture shop within 5 years. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy carpentry equipment

loans.name: Amma

texts.en:
Amma is a married woman with 2 children. She describes herself to be humble. She operates a retail shop where she sells soda, bread, milk,flour and other items. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals.

She describes her biggest business challenge to be high cost of products. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of bread, flour, soap and other items. Her business goal is to be a wholesaler within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She will use the anticipated profits to purchase land.

loans.use: to buy more stock of bread, flour, soap and other items

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a married woman with 2 children. She describes herself to be intelligent. She operates a farm where she grows bananas and has been involved in this business for 2 years. Her business is located in a strategic place.

She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to buy farm inputs. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to buy more farm inputs to enable her increase production.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Quraishia

texts.en:
Qurashia is the age of 61 and a mother of eight children living with her spouse and children in the area of Multan, Pakistan. She engages in embroidery to earn an income. She started her embroidery business six years ago because she wanted to help her husband support the family and meet the household expenses.

Qurashia buys materials such as hand embroidery kits, ribbon, needles and an embroidery machine from the market. Another person handles her transactions with her customers. She has decided that she would like to sell her embroidery items directly in the market so that she can earn a better profit for her family. She has become an expert in the embroidery business. So Qurashia requested a loan so she that will be able to buy raw materials from the market.

Qurashia will be thankful to Kiva and field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy embroidery raw material for herself.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Mary Ann is 35 years old and has three children are currently in school.

Mary Ann has a food vending business in the Philippines. Mary Ann requested a PHP 12000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients like spices, banana, sugar, cooking oil and other ingredients for her food production business.

Mary Ann has been in this business for 10 years. She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like spices, banana, sugar, cooking oil and other ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Nerlie

texts.en:
Nerlie is 27 years old and has two children.  Nerlie is married and has one child still in school.

Nerlie is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Nerlie requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Nerlie has been in this business for 5 years now, and has borrowed 2 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Nerlie would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica continues working as a Camfed Learner Guide who volunteers working with children in secondary school. Veronica has a shop, where she sells a variety of products such as sugar, salt, tea leaves, beans and rice. The profit from the shop helps her to repay her loan.

She is requesting a second loan from Kiva to increase her shop's stock by buying in bulk from a town where the price is low. Veronica plans to use the profit she will earn to support her family with everyday needs such as food, clothing and health care.

loans.use: to improve her business by purchasing merchandise in bulk and selling at retail.

loans.name: Abdulkarimu

texts.en:
Abdulkarimu is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. Before joining Babban Gona, Abdulkarimu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs.

With the help of this loan, Abdulkarimu can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. Abdulkarimu is thankful that he now has the opportunity to to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Thanks for supporting Farida, who sells women's clothing, with her first loan. She managed to repay the entire amount and is now requesting a second Kiva loan to purchase clothing in bulk to increase shop inventory.

Farida plans to use the profits she earns to expand her business. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two-and-a-half hours of volunteer work.

loans.use: To purchase up-to-date clothing designs

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en: Mwanaisha is a 20-year-old entrepreneur requesting a loan in order to buy charcoal. She lives in the Bagamoyo district. Mwanaisha volunteers as a Camfed leaner guide. She is requesting a Kiva loan to launch a venture in the charcoal business. She plans to use the profit she earns to help her family and support her parents with basic needs like shelter, clothes and food. The interest on her “social-interest” loan will be repaid through her weekly two and a half hours of volunteering.

loans.use: to buy charcoal.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy comes from a family of 8 siblings. She lives with her parents. Her father is a truck driver and her mother runs her own business selling groceries. Nancy is very happy to start running her own business as well. Her businesses will provide people in her community with access to financial services.

Nancy is requesting a loan in order to procure the working capital necessary to get her Zoona business started, so that she can begin growing her business and providing for herself. Nancy hopes to gain experience in the business. She is very excited about the opportunity of having her own Zoona business and dreams of earning enough money so that she can begin to expand her business.

Nancy is requesting a loan in order to procure working capital to get her Zoona business started, so that she may one day achieve her hopes and dreams. The loan will be used to purchase a Zoona branded Trolley and a mobile phone, which she will use to serve her customers. This loan will also provide Nancy with the float needed for her to serve her customers.

loans.use: to procure working capital to get her Zoona business started, so that can start offering mobile money services in Lilongwe and she may one day achieve her hopes and dreams

loans.name: Ulalia

texts.en: Ulalia is a 39 year old mother with 6 children and had a small business of selling vegetables (cabbage, eggplant, cucumber) in her community to earn a living. Ulalia requested for a loan to buy vegetable seeds, chemicals, wheelbarrow, water tank, rake, shovel, hand gloves and safety boots, to assist her run the business. She will expand her business using her profit. She became a member of SPBD in 2011.

loans.use: to buy vegetable seeds, chemicals, wheelbarrow, water tank, rake, shovel, hand gloves and safety boots,.

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus is a married man with 2 children. He describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle and has been involved in this business for 6 years. His business is located in a busy place and his primary customers are locals.

He describes his biggest business challenge to be high cost of fuel. He will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy another motorcycle. His business goal is to buy a taxi within 5 years. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is a single woman with 5 children. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a retail business where she sells books, stationery and also offers printing, photocopying services. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a busy place and her primary customers are locals.

She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of stationery. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of stationery to use for printing in her store.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 33 years old and single with two children. With two children in school, Marissa works very hard to provide for them.

Marissa runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, coffee, home product care, and other groceries.

Marissa has been in this business for 1 years and sells a variety of items. 

In the future, Marissa would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, coffee, home product care, and other groceries

loans.name: Abdu

texts.en:
Abdu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, he is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Abdu would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Abdu will store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a later date in the season when his can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000/Ha, Abdu now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Dorotea

texts.en:
Fifty-year old Dorotea display  snack in nearby school canteen in her town. She is married and has three grown children. She  runs a sari-sari(variety) store, selling basic household commodities like sugar, coffee, condiments,edible oil, bath soap, shampoo, tooth paste and soft drinks.
Her greatest monthly expenses goes for  food, and  house hold expenses like electric bill.
 
For the past 16 years, she has prepares snack food like puto(steam rice), banana cue( deep-fried banana in caramelized sugar). 

Dorotea  decided to join CEVI to access loans and boost her business.  She wants to buy more ingredients like banana, sugar, rice flour, bamboo skewer and additional capital for sari-sari(variety) store.
These will enables her to serve her customers and slowly pay her obligation.

She is looking forward to have a better living condition and a sustainable source of income by handling her both livelihood properly.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients like banana. sugar, rice flour, bamboo skewer and additional capital for sari-sari(variety) store

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a married woman with 2 children. She describes herself as a risk taker. She operates a farm where she grows tea. Her business is located in a fertile area. She describes her family challenge to be lack of clean water storage facility.

She will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy a water tank to store clean water for domestic use. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a married man with 6 children. He operates a retail business where he sells clothes which he has been involved in for 5 years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital.

He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. His business goal is to own a big clothes store within 5 years. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to purchase additional stock.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Nilma

texts.en:
Nilma is 38 years old and has one child. Nilma is married and has one child still in school.

Nilma is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Nilma requested a PHP 12000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Nilma has been in this business for 10 years now, and has borrowed 7 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Nilma would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Refije

texts.en: Refije's daughter is getting married soon, which will incur expenses of the union that must be paid as soon as possible. This loan will be used to pay for those marriage expenses.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter's marriage expenses, some as required from authorities and also some other ones

loans.name: Maximina

texts.en:
Maximina is 67 years old and married and she works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, canned goods, soap, shampoo, milk, etc.

Maximina has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future Maximina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, canned goods, soap, shampoo, milk, etc.

loans.name: Wilfresha

texts.en:
Wilfresha is a married woman with two children. She describes herself as creative. She operates a retail business where she sells sugar, bread, flour, soap and other items. She has been involved in this business for three years.

Her primary customers are locals. She says that her biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital. Her business goal is to own a big shop within five years.

This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She successfully repaid her previous loan. She will use this KES 60,000 loan to buy more sugar, flour, bread, milk and other items to sell.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, flour, bread, milk and other items to sell.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a married woman with six children. She describes herself as God fearing. She operates a retail business where she sells shoes. She has been involved in this business for five years.

Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She says that her biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years.

This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. She successfully repaid her previous loans. She will use this KES 60,000 loan to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is a married woman with five children. She describes herself as determined. She operates a retail business where she sells cereals. She also owns a farm where she grows potatoes, maize and other crops.

She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She says that her biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital.

She will use this KES 40,000 loan to buy farm inputs to enable her to grow more cereals. She hopes that in the future she will be prosperous. She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Alhassan

texts.en:
Alhassan is maize farmer from Dogon Juri village. As a member of Babban Gona, Alhassan is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support he has the oppotrtunity to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tones of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Alhassan would have had to sell his maize at Harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest to meet his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Alhassan can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Alhassan is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and in the end hopes to use his increased earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Taghrid

texts.en: Taghrid is a 43 year old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and two children still attending school. Her husband is the main income source in the family to satisfy the requirements of life and until now he earns a barely fair income. For that reason, today, she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to pay her children’s educational fees. She said that the loan will surely help her to register them with the coming school year what makes her very happy.

loans.use: to pay her children’s educational fees

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida is a 50-year-old woman from Clarin, Bohol. She is married with five children; two adult and three school aged children. Her husband is a farmer while Leonida is engaged in hog raising business. She has been running this business for three years. Aside from this, she also engaged in buying and selling food supplements. Leonida and her husband work together to provide the needs of their children. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets to raise and feed as well. She will also buy more food supplements to sell. With the loan we entrusted to her, we can possibly help this woman reach her goal. She wants to improve her business in the future for her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed; food supplements

loans.name: Jecinta

texts.en:
Jecinta is a married woman with 5 children. She describes herself to be active. She operates a farm where she keeps dairy cows and also grows fruits and has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals.

She describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. She will use the Kes 45,000 loan to buy farm inputs. Her business goal is to expand her farming business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a married woman. She has 2 children. She describes herself to be trustworthy. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals.

She describes her biggest business challenge to be low stock. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future, she will have improved standards of living.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 45 years old, married with four children. One of whom is in school, she is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Rosita has a food vending business in the Philippines. Rosita requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Rosita has been in this business for six years. In the future, Rosita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a married parent of three children. She works hard to support her family.

She is a hairdresser who provides perms, jell and weaving services to her customers in Ghana. She also earns income from selling hair products. Lydia is borrowing GHS 2,000 from ID Ghana to buy wigs, shampoo and cream that she will use to provide service to her customers.

Lydia has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from ID Ghana. She hopes that her hard work will help her realize her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy wigs, shampoo and cream that she will use to provide service to her customers.

loans.name: Hatixhe

texts.en:
Hatixhe must continue with the repairs of her poorly built house. There are so many more parts in the house that need immediate attention.

In the photograph, she is seen making thread from wool as the female older generation in the rural continue this craft to day. With the thread they then knit mostly socks, sweaters, scarves,hats and gloves.

loans.use: to make repairs to her house. She is very poor according to the national poverty level.

loans.name: Pae Kone Village Group 1

texts.en: Featured borrower, Khin aims to expand her livestock business by raising more ducks.  Some of her team members plan to purchase additional feeds.  The previous loan from Proximity Designs helped 26 group members cover each family's living cost and regulate monthly cash flows.  The affordable rates of their previous Kiva loan allowed the group members to cover monthly expenses.We could sense our customers's improved financial stability in their excitement for the upcoming Myanmar festival, Thandingyut where they feature an entire night of events with various friendly competitions.

loans.use: to help 26 villagers purchase ducks, good quality feeds and vitamins.

loans.name: Pilirani

texts.en:
Lucia is 24 years old. She is the last born in a family of three. Lucia grew up in a very close family. She enjoyed spending time with her brother and sister and cousins. Having this positive energy around her has had made her believe that she can achieve anything she sets her mind to.
Lucia is excited to start running her own business because it will give her an opportunity to meet a lot of new people in the community and provide a much needed service. Lucia says her community will benefit because they will not have to use any transport money to access financial services. Lucia’s business will provide financial services such as sending and receiving of money. 
When asked what challenges Lucia faces, she says it is not easy to live without an income, she explains that she failed to continue with her education because she and her parents were not able to afford the fees. Lucia is convinced that once she starts running her own business, she will have some money coming in and will not have to rely on her parents to buy her basic things like lotion and clothes. 
Lucia has applied for this loan in order to start running her own business as a Zoona mobile money transfer agent. The loan will be used as her start-up loan to purchase a trading trolley and a web enabled cell phone. The funds will also provide her with the money she needs as float in order to operate her business.
Lucia’s hopes and dreams are to run and operate her business and help other people to also open up their own businesses. She says that she would love to own a home one day so that she can keep her family together by giving them a place they can always go to.

loans.use: to start running her own business as a Zoona mobile money transfer agent so that she can provide financial services in her community

loans.name: Everket

texts.en:
Everket is a hardworking woman dealing in the sale of foods stuffs and gets additional income from cocoa growing. She is involved in the businesses with an intention of earning income to meet basic family needs and local people are her main customers.

She is challenged by competition because everyone in her area is into cocoa business during the season and low volume of sales that hinders future prospects of expanding her business and also building a good permanent house of her own. Everket has asked for a loan to buy more food stuffs like beans, cassava flour, ground nuts, cabbages, tomatoes and onions for resale.

loans.use: to buy more food stuffs like beans, cassava flour, ground nuts, cabbages, tomatoes and onions for resale .

loans.name: Manzoor

texts.en:
Manzoor is 48 years old, married woman running a business of milk selling for many years with the help of her husband. She was living a tough life some years ago; it was very difficult to bear her household expenditures. so she initiated her business. She has buffaloes for milking purpose. She sells the milk in her area. Her business is doing well enough to pay for her family’s expenses. She has 6 children and is a dedicated mother and wants the best for her children.

She has taken many loans from Kashf Foundation, now, she has requested for a loan of 45000 PKR to purchase one more buffalo for increasing milk sales to earn good amount of income to fulfill her dream of providing better living conditions to her children.

loans.use: to purchase one more buffalo for increasing milk sales to earn good amount of income to fulfill her dream of providing better living conditions to her children

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a married woman. She has five children. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells onions, potatoes, bananas and other items. She has been involved in this business for 15 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of products. She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of tomatoes, bananas and other vegetables. Her business goal is to be supplying supermarkets with vegetables within five years. This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to expand the business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tomatoes, bananas and other vegetables

loans.name: Dabo

texts.en:
Dabo is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, Dabo has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 Metric Tones of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Dabo would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs. With the help of this loan, Dabo can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Dabo will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2000/ha.

Dabo is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana, teacher by her profession, has been also involved in retail business for 3 years. She trades with cosmetic products from her house, and after hard working years, has been able to gain a loyal client base..

Svetlana asks this loan to purchase cosmetic supplies to cover her customers' orders and gather income for her family.
Svetlana lives with her husband and son in Vanadzor town and dreams of having a developed and successful business in the future.

loans.use: to pay for cosmetic supplies to cover customers' orders and gather income for her family

loans.name: Jamima

texts.en:
Jamima is a maize farmer from Dankwaire village. As a member of Babban Gona, Jamima is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support she has the oppotrtunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tons of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria. Before joining Babban Gona, Jamima would have had to sell her maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest, to meet her immediate cash needs.

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Jamima can store her maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. Jamima is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and in the end, hopes to use her increased earnings to move to the city with her family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is a married woman. She has five children. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells livestock. She has been involved in this business for 25 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are locals. She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy more livestock. Her business goal is to be selling livestock countrywide within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loans were repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to expand the business.

loans.use: to buy more livestock

loans.name: Mileydi Esther

texts.es:
Ella es Mileydi, es una mujer cuyo ambición pro progresar, pro salir adelante la llevo a montar un negocio de comercio de ropa y productos de uso personal, actividad que inicio por necesidad económica ya que es madre cabeza de familia.
Está mujer empezó con un capital muy b ajo, pero con una gran ilusión, y con su esfuerzo y perseverancia ayudaron a consolidar un negocio que tiene un futuro enorme pues tiene buenos clientes y ha crecido exponencialmente,
Ahora a sus 27 años de edad quiere solicitar un préstamo de un monto considerable pues hará una gran inversión para crecer.
El apoyo económico lo quiere invertir en la compra de productos de uso personal, ropa y calzado, también comprara estantería pues montara su punto de venta ya que anteriormente vendía puerta a puerta.
Apoyar esta empresaria, es apoyar el crecimiento, apoyar el cambio, incentivar el emprendimiento y aplaudir la iniciativa de salir delante de madres cabeza de familia.
texts.en:
This is Mileydi, a woman whose ambition to progress and to get ahead has driven her to start a business selling clothes and personal use products. She started this business due to financial need now that she is the female head of household.

This woman started with a very small capital but with a big dream, and her effort and perseverance helped to consolidate a business that has an enormous future as it has good customers and has grown exponentially.

Now, at 27 years old, she wants to ask for a loan of a considerable sum as she is going to make a big investment in order to grow.

She wants to invest the financial support into the purchase of personal use products, clothes and shoes. She will also buy shelving to put up in a shop as previously she made her sales door-to-door.

Supporting this businesswoman means supporting growth, supporting change, incentivising entrepreneurs and celebrating female head of household's initiatives to get ahead.

loans.use: to buy products for personal use, clothes and shoes, as well as shelving to put up in the shop.

loans.name: Maria De Jesus

texts.es: Maria de 42 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, ella posee una pequeña tienda ubicada en su lugar de residencia desde hace 15 años, tambien se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pupusas, gracias a su trabajo es como ella logra salir adelante con los gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, la clienta esta solicitando nuevamente un crédito pero en esta ocasion es para la compra de huevos, cereales, golosinas, aceite, macarrones, detergente, etc. y asi poder tener mas ingresos economicos.
texts.en:
Maria is 42 years old and lives in her own house with her family. She has a small shop which has been located in her place of residence for the last 15 years. She also works making and selling 'pupusas' (stuffed tortillas).

Her job is the reason why she has managed to get ahead with her household expenses. She is currently asking for a loan, but on this occasion it is to buy eggs, cereals, sweets, oil, macaroons, detergent and other products so she can have more financial income.

loans.use: to buy eggs, cereals, sweets, oil, macaroons, detergent and other items.

loans.name: Kalyskan

texts.ru: Калыскан, 50 лет, замужем, мать 4 детей. На протяжении 31 года занимается животноводством и полеводством, мастер в своем деле. По хозяйству активно помогает вся семья. Образование у Калыскан среднее. Начала бизнес с 1,200 сом (KGS) и достигла больших успехов. В хозяйстве имеет 2 коровы, 20 овец. Также есть земельный надел, на 0,50 ГА собственной и 1,0 Га арендованной земли она выращивает ячмень. Калыскан обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом, в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 2 коров. На доходы от кредита Калыскан хочет расширить свое хозяйство и построить сараи для скота.
texts.en:
Kalyskan is 50 and married with four children. She has been working in animal husbandry and agriculture for 31 years and is an expert in her field. Her whole family helps her with the farm. She has a high school education, started the business with 1,200 KGS and has been very successful. She has two cows and 20 sheep on her farm as well as 0.5 hectares of her own and 1 hectare of rented land where she grows barley.

Kalyskan has approached Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase two cows. She wants to use profits from the loan to expand her farm and build a barn for her livestock.

loans.use: to purchase two cows to increase her herd

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a concrete hollow block machine.

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en:
Rubina is 39 years old and married with five children, who are in school, Rubina works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, noodles, egg, personal care products, etc. .

Rubina has been in this business for 5 years.

In the future Rubina would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, noodles, egg, personal care products, etc.

loans.name: Antonio De Jesús

texts.es: Antonio es un microempresario de 29 años que le gusta enfrentar retos en su vida, para él es muy motivante ser empresario independiente y poder tener su propia autonomía en todos los aspectos de su vida, es por ello que emprendió con ayuda de su familia en las instalaciones de su vivienda un expendio de bebidas al detal y al por mayor.  Utilizó en este proyecto sus ahorros en los que los resultados fueron los esperados y en la actualidad cuenta con cuatro años de funcionamiento con mucho deseos de seguir creciendo en su negocio. Sus principales clientes son sus vecinos, amigos y familiares quienes llegan hasta su residencia en busca de algún refresco o bebida alcohólica, para departir y pasar un momento de esparcimiento y relajación. Los principales productos que comercializa son cervezas nacionales y extranjeras, gaseosas, jugos y bebidas energizantes y los días en que más vende son los fines de semana.  Como estamos entrando a temporadas de fiesta Antonio está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, que invertirá en canastas de cervezas, gaseosas, jugos naturales y energizantes.  Su meta a futuro es continuar ayudando económicamente a su familia y contar con más espacio y capacidad en su negocio.
texts.en:
Antonio is a 29 year old micro entrepreneur who likes to face challenges in his life. It is very motivating for him to be an independent entrepreneur and to be able to have autonomy in all aspects of his life. It is because of this that with the help of his family in getting established in his home, he started a small store of retail and wholesale drinks. He used his savings on this project and the results were what were hoped for. He currently has four years in operation with a big desire to continue growing his business.

His principal customers are his neighbors, friends and family members who come to his residence in search of a refreshment or alcoholic beverage in order to mingle and have a moment of entertainment and relaxation. The main products that he sells are national and foreign beers, sodas, juices and energy drinks. The days that he sells the most are on the weekends.

Since we are entering the party season, Antonio is applying for a Kiva loan which is the first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. He will invest in beer crates, sodas, natural juices and energy drinks. His goal for the future is to continue helping his family economically and have more space and capacity in his business.

loans.use: to invest in beer crates, sodas, natural juices and energy drinks.

loans.name: Pilirani

texts.en:
Pilirani is 21 years old. She would like to be in college and do what people her age do, but she can’t because she did not have the money to pay college tuition. She explains that growing up in a big family was challenging because they did not have much. Paying school fees was hard and Pilirani had to work hard by ding odd jobs around her neighborhood to try to pay for her school fees and complete her high school education. Pilirani has not given up hope of ever going to college.

She has completed a training with Zoona to become a Zoona agent so that she can set up her own of mobile money transfers.
Pilirani’s biggest dream is to expand her business beyond her town. She intends to be able to handle huge sums of money as this will enable her to have more profits. However, Pilirani faces the challenge of not having her own working capital to start running the business. When she gets the loan, Pilrani will purchase the equipment needed for her to start transacting. These are a web-enabled phone and a trading trolley as well as some cash at hand so that she can serve customers.

Pilirani says running her own business will change her life because It will allow her to earn an income which in turn will improve her life. Her basic needs will be met and she will be able to live more comfortably.

loans.use: to purchase a web-enabled phone and trading trolley as well as prove the funds needed to serve customers when she starts operating her mobile money transfer business. .

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is a 42-year-old married woman and has five children. Her oldest child is 22 while the youngest is 3.

She resides in the town of Talibon, Bohol. She owns and runs a sari-sari (variety) store, catering mostly to neighbors in her place.

She sells commodities like rice, soft drinks, cooking oil, condiments, noodles, soap, and beverages.

Aside from running a store, she also engages in a fish-vending business. She sells fresh fish to the locals in her place, as an additional source of income.

She has decided to join CEVI to access loans and boost her business. With the 50,000 PHP, she wants to buy more stock of fish and merchandise for her store like soft drinks, rice, and canned goods. With these, she can display a variety of fish that could attract more customers. On the other hand, she can also maintain an inventory of merchandise to prevent stock shortages.

In the future, Analiza is determined that she will become successful in both of her sources of income to improve the family's living condition and also to support the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish and merchandise for her store like soft drinks, rice, and canned goods.

loans.name: Victor

texts.es: Victor es un joven muy esforzado que labora en su puesto de ventas de comida. Solicita un préstamo de un millón cincuenta mil colones (₡ 1 050 000), para la compra de equipos de cocina que le permitan elaborar las comidas de una forma más rápida y eficiente.  De esta manera logrará ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Victor is a very driven young man who makes a living running a food stand.

He is requesting a loan in the amount of 1,050,000 colones in order to buy kitchen equipment so that he can prepare his meals more quickly and efficiently. This will allow him to give his customers better service.

loans.use: to buy kitchen equipment.

loans.name: Cancuncito Group

texts.es:
La extensión del agua y los cerros formados por los caprichos de la naturaleza dan origen a la comunidad  donde la mayoría de los habitantes se dedica a la pesca y venta de mojarra. “Rodeada de cerros” es el significado del nombre de la comunidad, que hace honor a su panorama. 
En este lugar se formó el grupo “Cancuncito” que se ubica en una pequeña isla que se forma cuando liberan el agua de la presa. El grupo está integrado por: María D. y Honoria quienes se dedican a la pesca y venta de mojarra; Sabina, Antolina, Virginia y María G., a la reventa del mismo tipo de pescado; Maricela, a la venta de calzado, antojitos mexicanos y tamales; Faustino, a la venta de refresco; Jacobo y Bibiana, a la venta de nieves; Octavia, a la venta de cosméticos y Bulmaro, a la venta de caña de azúcar.
Jacobo es un joven de 21 años de edad, aún vive con sus padres y es un chico muy trabajador; aprendió de sus padres a elaborar nieves y paletas, actividad a la que dedica su tiempo para apoyar en los gastos de su hogar.
Al principio, fue complicado lograr la consistencia correcta de la nieve, pero sus padres continuaban dándole recomendaciones que puso en práctica hasta lograrlo. Todas las tardes, entre los tres preparaban los helados y paletas de distintos sabores, para al día siguiente ofrecer a los clientes un postre refrescante. 
Desde hace 2 años, Jacobo suele salir después de mediodía a vender los productos, en una pequeña vitrina coloca los conos, cucharitas, vasos, servilletas. Mientras él recorre las calles de las comunidades, sus padres venden en casa.
Las ganancias obtenidas le ha permitido a la familia hacer remodelaciones a su vivienda, comprar muebles y un congelador para las paletas. Con el nuevo préstamo comprará azúcar, fruta, picante líquido y en polvo, leche, sal, servilletas y gas para los congeladores. Jacobo sueña con tener una peletería y brindar trabajo a otras personas.
“Gracias por creer en nosotros y apoyarnos con préstamos para fortalecer nuestras actividades” expresaron los clientes del grupo.
*La fotografía fue tomada en el patio de la casa de Maricela, Jacobo es el más joven y se encuentra de pie detrás de sus compañeros.
texts.en:
An expanse of water and the mountains created by nature's whim originated this community, most of whose residents work in the fishing industry. This is where the Cancuncito group was founded. It is located on a small island that is formed when the water of the dam is drained.

The group comprises: María D. and Honoria, who work fishing and selling sea bream; Sabina, Antolina, Virginia, and María G, who also sell the same type of fish; Maricela, who sells shoes as well as Mexican snacks and tamales; Faustino, who sells soft drinks; Jacobo and Bibiana, who sell ice cream; Octavia,who sells cosmetics; and Bulmaro, who sells sugar cane.

Jacobo is a 21-year-old young man. He still lives with his parents and is a very hard worker. He learned how to make ice cream and popsicles from his parents. He works in this business in order to help support their household.

In the beginning, it was hard for him to achieve the right consistency for his ice cream, but his parents kept giving him advice, and he heeded their recommendations until he was successful. Every afternoon, all three of them prepare the different flavors of ice cream and popsicles in order to have refreshing desserts to offer their customers the following day.

For the past two years, Jacobo has been going out after noon to sell his product. He places the cones, spoons, cups, and napkins in a small display case. While he works as a local street vendor, his parents run a stand at home.

Jacobo's earnings have allowed the family to remodel their home, buy furniture, and purchase a new freezer for their popsicles. He will use this loan to buy sugar, fruit, hot sauce, chile powder, milk, salt, napkins, and gas for the freezers. His dream is to run his own ice cream shop and create jobs for others.

“Thank you for believing in us and supporting us with loans so that we can strengthen our businesses," say the borrowers of this group.

The picture was taken on the patio at Maricela's home. Jacobo is the youngest and is standing behind his fellow borrowers.

loans.use: to buy sugar, fruit, hot sauce, chile powder, milk, salt, napkins, and gas.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a married man with 3 children. He describes himself to be patient. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located in a busy place and his primary customers are locals.

He will use the Kes 60,000 loan to buy a new motorcycle. His business goal is to have more motorcycles within 5 years. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to buy land.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Nancy is a Kiva borrower. She describes herself to be humble. She operates a retail business where she sells fish. She has been involved in this business for 1 years. Her primary customers are locals. She will use the Kes 10,000 loan to buy more stock of fish. Her business goal is to own a hotel within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz is 37 years old, married woman. She has been successfully running a small store with her husband at the corner of her house. She sells various beauty products, hair accessories along with spools of threads and ribbons. Through her business she makes enough to meet the expenses of her 3 children.

Currently, she requested a loan of 30000 PKR to purchase more beauty products such as lotions, cleansers and set of lipsticks along with hair accessories to cater maximum customers for generating healthier source of income. She is positive about her future earnings and will spend the part of her income on buying more items for her store.

loans.use: to purchase more beauty products such as lotions, cleansers and set of lipsticks along with hair accessories to cater maximum customers

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is a man who has many dreams and great objectives in his life. He is happy because of the loan he received to buy the land he wanted so much, where he will soon build his house. Nicholas is very excited about this and grateful to the Kiva investors who want to support him to achieve his dreams.

To improve his family quality of life, Nicholas has decided to take advantage of the opportunity to buy second hand clothing from one wholesale market and sell to his customers at another market. He is doing this in order to generate more income to be able to take care of his family, his future project and his business.

Nicholas is a family man who has a wife and three children. Nicholas' major goal is to provide a better quality of life to her family.

loans.use: to buy second hand clothing from one wholesale market and sell to his customers at another market.

loans.name: Carlos Augusto

texts.es: Carlos es un hombre emprendedor de 33 años, su principal motivación para iniciar su negocio fue el desempleo, por lo que necesitaba buscar las maneras de generar ingresos para su familia. El inició ofreciendo el servicio de video juegos por hora o fracción, luego empezó a comercializar accesorios para celulares, servicio de llamadas por minutos, golosinas, y productos de tocador. Hoy en día cuenta con una clientela fidelizada entre ellos sus vecinos, amigos, referidos y transeúntes del sector, a quienes les ofrece sus servicios diariamente en el horario de 8 a.m. a 9 p.m. Sus compras las realiza a almacenes y a operadores de telefonía celular, estas compras las cancela de contado, pero en ocasiones no alcanza a llevar todo lo necesario para surtir el negocio por tener insuficiente capital, actualmente está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo mediante el cual comprará nuevas versiones de video juegos, paquetes recargas de minutos a celulares, golosinas, talcos para cuerpo, desodorantes y colonias. Carlos es padre de un hijo de 10 años a quien desea brindar un mejor porvenir, su meta es fortalecer mas su capital y obtener mejores resultados.
texts.en:
Carlos is an enterprising, 33-year-old man. His main motivation for starting his business was unemployment, which is why he needed to look for ways of generating income for his family.

He started by offering a video game service by hour or part hour, then he started to sell accessories for mobile phones, a call service by the minute, sweets, and dressing table products. Nowadays, he has a loyal clientele, amongst them his neighbours, friends, recommendations and passers-by in the area, to whom he offers his services daily from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m.

He buys his goods at market and from mobile phone operators. He makes these purchases in cash but sometimes he fails to carry everything he needs to stock his business due to insufficient capital. He is currently applying for a Kiva loan, the first transaction that he is making with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with which he will buy new versions of video games, packets of mobile phone top-up cards, sweets, talcum powder, deodorants and perfumes.

Carlos is father to one 10-year-old son, who he hopes to provide with a better future. His aim is to strengthen his capital and gain better results.

loans.use: to buy new versions of video games, packets of mobile phone top-up cards, sweets, talcum powders, deodorants and perfumes.

loans.name: Ayesha

texts.en:
Ayesha is 50 years old, married lady and is running a small general store in her community for many years with her husband who is also shown in the photo. She offers a variety of grocery items at a reasonable price and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. She makes enough to provide for her family.

To make her store fully stocked she requested for a loan of 30000 PKR which she will use to buy rice, sugar, grains, biscuits, oil and flour from the market at lower rates to make her stock available for her customers. In this way she would be able to meet the increasing demand consistently. Ayesha wishes to utilize part of her revenues on providing good quality life to her family members.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, grains, biscuits, oil and flour from the market at lower rates to make her stock available for her customers

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is 26, married and, is financially responsible for his 2 children as well as his aging mother. 2 years ago, he started a small grocery store project and is, now, requesting 5000 EGP loan to buy some grocery products such as oil, rice, canned foods, and pasta to meet the increasing demands of his customer since there are not many other grocery stores is his area.

loans.use: To buy some grocery products such as oil, rice, canned foods, and pasta

loans.name: Briskila

texts.en:
Briskila is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating of a good harvest this season, Briskila has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. Before joining Babban Gona, Briskila would have had to sell her maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet her immediate cash needs.

With the help of this loan, Briskila can store her maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. As a Babban Gona member, Briskila will benefit from marketing support that could see her generate earnings of up to $2000/ha. is thankful that she now has the opportunity to to improve the life of her children and family and looks forward to using her additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest .

loans.name: Madres Unidas Group

texts.es: Soledad es una mujer emprendedora madre de dos hijos ya mayores de edad,se dedica  a la venta de cosméticos por catalogo dedicándose de tres a cuatro horas diarias, sus principales clientes son familiares y amigos de la zona donde vive que siempre la buscan por los productos de buena calidad,precios accesibles y buena asesoría que da a sus clientes, se siente muy contenta de haber logrado el préstamo ya que le permitirá comprar productos como cremas perfumes joyas por mayor y así poder obtener mas ganancia y tener mejor calidad de vida. Agradece a los inversionistas Kiva por el apoyo brindado y dice no dejen de ayudar a gente que lucha día a día por salir adelante.
texts.en:
Soledad is an enterprising woman. She is a mother of two, but her children are all grown. She works selling cosmetics by catalog, and does so for between three and four hours a day. Her main customers are family members and friends living in her area. They always come to her because she offers high quality products, affordable prices, and good advice.

She is very happy to be able to access a loan such as this one, because it will allow her to buy products like lotions, fragrances, and wholesale jewelry so that she can make higher profits and have a better quality of life.

She wants to thank Kiva lenders for their support and urges them to continue helping people who work hard and fight for a better life.

loans.use: to buy products like lotions, jewelry, fragrances, and more.

loans.name: Zubiada

texts.en:
Financial constraints alongside the want for a better life and good quality education for her 5 children are only a few but valuable factors that encouraged Zubiada to start her business by taking a loan from Kashf Foundation. Zubiada is 46 years old and a married woman. In order to meet her household expenses she started her business selling animals.

She buys animals (baby goats & calves) at low prices, brings them up and then sells them out in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute in the family income. She also sells milk to generate an extra amount of income. She needs to improve her business to bear her household expenses.

For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied a loan of PKR 45000 to purchase more animals to inflate her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income level.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to increase her sales.

loans.name: Najma

texts.en:
Day by day, increasing expenditures but not having the ability to meet them compelled Najma to initiate her own business selling animals. She is 35 years old, married and doing her business with the help of her husband. Her business has provided her family with a decent life. She is a mother of three children. She is working very hard to provide her family with the basic necessities of life. 

She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR. She intends to use this loan amount to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers. She is confident that she can further expand her business with the help of future loans

loans.use: to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers.

loans.name: Rupani

texts.en:
Rupani is 46 years old married man, from Tbilisi, particularly Ponichala settlement. He has school aged daughter and son, and wife, who helps her husband to make the living wage for their family. It's already 12 years, they are involved in trading business. Rupani and his wife buy greens locally at wholesale prices, that are sold at the open market with price mark-ups. This is the only source of income for his family, that needs financial support to give their children good education for progressing in life.

Rupani has been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. Rupani plans to purchase a second-hand car and start providing taxi service among local people. He will get the additional source of income, that will greatly assist Rupani and he will be able to improve his economic situation and give his family a better style of life.

loans.use: to make additional source of income and start taxi business.

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en: Sabah is 44, married, and has 3 sons and one daughter. She has a small fattening project. She is requesting 5000 EGP loan to buy a head of cattle to increase her sales of milk, cheese and butter and sell the calves.

loans.use: to buy a head of cattle. .

loans.name: Joy-

texts.en:
Joy is asking for a loan of UGX 500,000 to buy merchandise, such as soap, sugar, and packed salt, and dry foodstuffs like maize flour and beans, to sell to boost her retail business.

She is 30 years old, married, and lives in Bundibugyo, Uganda. She raised initial capital from farming and was able to start her retail shop seven years ago. She is hardworking and would love to see her family live a better life. This compels her to work and raise income for her family's upkeep.

She has a business goal of developing economically and becoming financially stable to start a bigger wholesale shopping center in town.

loans.use: to buy merchandise, such as soap, sugar, and packed salt, and dry foodstuffs like maize flour and beans, to sell.

loans.name: Christo Nti Group

texts.en:
The group Christo nti are starting it's second cycle with ID-Ghana. The group is made up of two members, and is represented by Lydia. The group members run a variety of small businesses including: selling smoke fish and hair dressing service.

The loan that the group takes out will benefit the small-businesswomen in the group. This is the second time Lydia has been involved with ID-Ghana, she joined up on the invitation of a friend who is already part of the organization.

Lydia has been selling smoke fish for 3 years from house to house. Lydia will use the money from the loan to buy more fish, firewood which she will smoke and sell to customers. This business allows Lydia to make money to support her family economically. 

When asked what she likes about ID-Ghana, Lydia responded that she enjoys the trainings and the health service that the organization offers.

loans.use: to buy more fish, firewood which she will smoke and sell to customers.

loans.name: Sunisi

texts.en:
Sunisi is a maize farmer from Doka village. As a Babban Gona member, Sunisi is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 Metric Tones of Maize per Hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Sunisi would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs. Sunisi will use this loan to store the maize he harvests, enabling him to delay it’s sale until a later period in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price. 

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Sunisi no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000/Ha, Sunisi hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell maize for low prices at harvest

loans.name: Martina

texts.es: Martina de 48 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus tres hijas, ella se dedica a la elaboracion y venta de tamales y quesadillas, y gracias a ese trabajo es como ha podido salir adelante, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda repellando las paredes de la sala pero como no posee suficiente capital esta solicitando un credito para la compra de materiales de contruccion y asi poder tener una mejor vivienda sinse pueda vivir con su familia.
texts.en: Martina is 48 years old and lives at home with her husband and three daughters. She works making and selling tamales and quesadillas, and thanks to this work, she has been able to get ahead. She wants to improve her home by plastering the walls in the living room, but since she does not have enough money, she is requesting a loan to purchase construction supplies.This way she can have a better home to live in with her family.

loans.use: to purchase construction supplies.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas De La H Group

texts.es: Este es el nuevo grupo “MUJERES UNIDAS DE LA H” conformada por 05 socios emprendedores. Este es el caso  Norma de 61 años de edad casada con 3 hijos. Ella se dedica a la venta de tejidos confeccionados por ella misma como chompas chalecos. Desde hace más de 15 años que tiene dicho negocio. Su mayor deseo es de poder ampliar su negocio. Solicito el crédito para la compra de lana e hilos. El grupo “mujeres unidas de la h” está agradecido con las personas de kiva que hicieron posible este crédito, pues le permite mejorar su calidad de vida. Norma es la tercera del lado derecho viste polo color ROSADO.
texts.en:
The name of this new group is Mujeres De La H. It comprises five enterprising members.

One of them is Norma, who is 61 years old and married with three children. She works selling textiles, which she knits herself, such as sweaters and vests. She has been in this business for over fifteen years. Her main desire is to expand her business. She is requesting this loan to buy yarn and thread.

This group is grateful to everyone at Kiva who will make this loan possible, because it will allow them to improve their quality of life.

Norma is the third borrower from the right, wearing a pink polo shirt.

loans.use: to buy yarn and thread.

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras De Santa Lidia Group

texts.es: Joseph es un joven de 23 años de edad padre de un hijo de tres años alquila un kiosko dentro de un colegio, ofrece productos de golosinas y cafetería,emprendió este negocio por que le gusta los retos y gracias al apoyo de un familiar puede trabajar independientemente ya que un año atrás trabajaba en una fabrica. Joseph se siente orgulloso de poder sacar adelante a su familia y poder emprender su propio negocio sus clientes son alumnos y profesores  que están a gusto por el servicio  que les brinda.el préstamo que solicitó lo invertirá para la compra de golosinas y bebidas y así poder ampliar mas su negocio con diferente variedad de productos y obtener mas ganancias.agradece a los inversionistas Kiva por el apoyo y se siente feliz que le den la oportunidad de crecer y así dar mejor calidad de vida a su familia y dice: Su ayuda me impulsa a salir adelante Gracias por confiar en nosotros.
texts.en:
Joseph is a 23 year old young man and the father of a 3 year old son. He rents a kiosk inside a school, where he sells candy and cafeteria products. He started this business because he likes challenges and thanks to the help of a family member he can work for himself, as one year before he was working in a factory.

Joseph is proud of being able to get his family ahead and be able to start his own business. His clients are students and professors who like the service that he provides. He is requesting the loan to invest in the purchase of candies and soft drinks to be able to expand his business with a different variety of products and make more profit. He is grateful to the Kiva lenders for their support and he feels happy that they provide him the opportunity to grow and be able to give his family a better quality of living. He says "Your help propels me ahead. Thank you for having confidence in us.

loans.use: to buy sweets and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to invest in: roofing, nails and to pay for labor to repair the damaged parts of her home.

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.es: Jorge de 36 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposa y sus tres hijos, el se dedica al cultivo de caña de azucar desde hace 10 años e inicio con capital propio y es asi como puede solventar algunos de los gastos que se le presentan en su hogar, el esta solicitando un credito para la compra de abonos, controles de plagas, etc. para tener un buen cultivo de caña y asi tener mejores ingresos economicos.
texts.en: Jorge is 36 years old. He lives in his own house with his wife and their three children. He has worked  cultivating sugarcane for 10 years. He started with his own capital, and this is how he is able to pay for some of his household expenses. He is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers, plague controls, etc. in order to have a good crop of sugarcane, and have better financial income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, plague controls, etc.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en: Benson is a married man. He has 3 children. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a farm where he grows carrots, maize, carrots and other crops. He has been involved in this business for 2 years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. He will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy farm inputs. His business goal is to be prosperous within 5 years. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Yona

texts.en:
Yona who is in who is in his early 40s is married with seven children. Two of them are in school and five of them, are grown up. He has been running two projects, selling milk and a retail shop for four years now. He works from 08am to 09pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Yona's 22nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase on the milk stock, to extend her shop, renovate her shop by putting tiles, to buy up to date milk storing machines and has managed to pay back all his loans successfully. He used the profit to pay school fees, built his house, to repay loan, bought a TV set, sofa set, bought a plot of land, reinvest in business and covered household expenses, increase on the milk stock, to meet his customers' requirement and to buy the fast moving items in his shop. He dreams of expanding his business.

Yona will be accountable for paying back his loan.

loans.use: to increase on the milk stock, to meet his customers' requirement, bought the fast moving items in his shop.

loans.name: Nver

texts.en:
Nver rents a store in the center of Vanadzor town, where he sells electrical goods. His main support and partner is his wife, Amalya, who runs the store with Nver. They work hard to keep the stock in the store updated and meet their customers' demand. Nver requested this loan to purchase new stock of electronic goods to have good sales in coming holiday season and gather income for the expansion of the business. 
Nver hopes that additional income gathered from the sale will permit him to enlarge the store and provide better living conditions to his wife and their 3-years old daughter.

loans.use: to pay for new stock of electronic goods to have good sales in coming holiday season and gather income for the expansion of the business

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: It was hard for Nasreen to manage her household expenses with the small income of her husband. Nasreen is a 30-year-old married woman. She is a mother of two children.  Some years ago, she started her business selling animals in her community. Her husband fully supports and assists her with her work. Now, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR. She wants to use this loan amount to purchase more cattle for reselling in the market. Nasreen has gained great confidence in the business as she has learned how to deal with other individuals within the business, allowing her to feel empowered.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle for reselling in the market

loans.name: Omar

texts.en: Omar is 21, single and runs a small fattening project along with his aging father. He takes good care of the cattle (cleaning, veterinary care and fattening). He is requesting a 5,000 EGP loan to buy a head of cattle to expand his project.

loans.use: to buy a head of cattle.

loans.name: Kunan Llankarisum Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “KUNAN LLANKARISUM”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Huayopata, perteneciente a la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Luzmila ella es casada y tiene 64 años y tiene 6 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de cultivo de frutas, la socia tiene un terreno donde cultiva plátanos, café, mandarinas y naranjas, la socia trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 5:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar su terreno de cultivo. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar semillas y fertilizantes.
El socio que esta con una cara tapada no pertence al banco comunal Kunan Llankarisum.
Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de animales, negocio de agricultura, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida.
